---------------
Foreign Office,
June 3rd, 1918.
My dear Milner :-
With the Secretary of State's concurrence I enclose to you copy of a letter which I have received from the French Embassy relating to the possible recruitment of Irishmen for the French forces, and which requires an answer.
I have no doubt as to what my own views are on this subject, but the matter seems to be one of such high military and political importance that it is desirable to have the definite opinion of the Government upon the questions raised in this letter.
Yours sincerely,
(Signed).. HARDINGE OF P.
----------------
War. Office,
Whitehall, S.W.1.
6th June, 1918.
Dear Campbell,
Lord Hardinge sent to Lord Milner a day or two age a copy of a letter which he had received from Monsieur de Fleuriau, regarding the enlistment of Irishmen into the French Army. The Secretary of State, thinks that it is really a question of Cabinet importance, though, from the point of view of the War Office, he and the Army Council see no great, military objection to the suggestion.
Yours sincerely,
(Signed) H. J. CREEDY..
R.H.Campbell, Esq., C.M.G..
